title: young people work economy moving
story: COVID- has delivered a stinging haymaker to the UK economy.The question now is how quickly it will get off the floor.And the truth is, as with so much right now, nobody quite knows.But two things are certain: A recession is coming, and the longer lockdown lasts, the longer Britain will spend on the canvas.So getting Britain’s economy going again must be a priority.And as we find out more and more about who is at risk from this plague, it is becoming increasingly clear that getting people like me — the young — back to work is the first and most sensible step on the road to recovery.We all know that coronavirus hits the oldest hardest.Nobody proposing lting lockdown measures is ignoring the horrendous inidual tragedies of all of those who pass.Every time the number of deaths goes up by just one, that is another family who have lost a dear loved one.But that does not change the fact that out of the more than , Brits who have sadly succumbed to Covid-, fewer than  have been under .I have lost count of the number of conversations I have had with fed-up friends who, like me, are desperate to get back to work, to continue with their hard-fought-for careers.If anyone might be safe toto work — and, of course, no one is completely safe from this bastard of a virus — then it is us.Just about every measure of the economy, from car sales to manufacturing performance, has hit a record low over the last few weeks — and that will only get worse.Some economic forecasters reckon it could take more than three years to get the economy back to where it was at the start of .And top economic wonks at the Institute For Fiscal Studies reckon youngsters will be hit hardest by the coming recession. I am , so when I joined the workforce we were in the midst of a financial crisis that plunged the economy into paralysis.I have endured years of political to-ing and fro-ing over spending, infrastructure projects and — whether you voted for it or not — Westminster’s tortuous Brexit chicanery that has slowed down economic growth.The price  Real wages, measured alongside inflation, only got back above their  levels this year.House prices shot up to unaffordable levels, with governments promising to build the houses we need but failing miserably to take on the vested interests that stand in the way.Young people could already only dream of owning a home before the world shut down.Just this week, a friend sent round a story on WhatsApp about the possibility of house prices collapsing.We all just laughed and agreed we still could not get anywhere near a deposit, and not because we have been enjoying too much avocado toast.And just as we looked forward to a British bounce once Brexit was in the rear-view mirror, now a global pandemic has made  look like nothing more than a trailer for the main event in which this young generation, yet again, gets a starring role.It is not just about getting money moving and business booming, either.The temporary schemes introduced by the Government to get people through the worst of this crisis will leave a borrowing pile that not even Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell could have dreamed up.Most likely, that means higher taxes and lower spending for decades. In short, Britain’s under-s are being condemned to years of an economy going backwards.So it is time for them to be allowed back to work and start the recovery. We should all be invested in British companies’ success.The better they do, the more jobs they create, the more they can pay, the better le is. Yes, there is a risk to getting the young back to work.But witness the orderly queues outside supermarkets and the pavement shuffle dance that we have all perfected to give each other space.The public, young and old, understand the threat of this virus.We invented all these video apps everyone is now socialising on. We are more than happy to use them for a little while longer.As for employers, they have built everything from thriving construction businesses to high-tech apps.It is not going to be beyond them to install plastic screens in the office, and nor are Lisa in marketing and Phil in accounts going to make like Professor Pantsdown in the filing cupboard.Are we prepared to trust our fellow Brits, take that risk and allow the next generation a better chance to succeed Even some of those in the highest at-risk groups will acknowledge we cannot live in economic shutdown forever.Even the boffins at Oxford know a vaccine will take months,not years.AndTikTok-ing millennials are not exactly winning much sympathy, what about the parents of young kids Anybody looking after children at home right now knows full well their productivity is close to zero.They need schools and nurseries open, too.Britain’s most dynamic cities and companies are being driven by the young, from the video game industry in Dundee to the start-up hubs of Shoreditch.They have had a decade of flatlining wages, a housing crisis and now the corona crash. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: THE Duchess of Cambridge is launching a photo project to show how families coped with lockdown.Their selfies will go up in London’s National Portrait Gallery.Kate, , said: “We’ve all been struck by the incredible images which have given us an insight into the stories of people.“Some desperately sad images showing the human tragedy of this pandemic.“And there are uplting pictures showing people coming together to support the vulnerable.”The categories are Helpers and Heroes, Your New Normal and Acts of Kindness.Photos already submitted include a photo of Florence, three, and Edith, one, were snapped pressing their tiny hands against the windowpane, withAnother harrowing photo in the collection shows an intensive care nurse suffering welts and marks on her face following a -hour sht wearing PPE.One hundred shortlisted portraits will then feature in the gallery when lockdown is lted before being shown across the country.Organisers said the photos will be judged on the emotion and experience rather than technical expertise.To submit an image visit www.npg.org.uk before June .To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast heatwave temperature bank holiday
story: The warm weather has been forecast to sweep northwards from the Spanish region bringing the hot conditions to the UK.Britons have basked in the glorious sunshine over the last few weeks, with much of the UK only able to enjoy the warm conditions in their gardens and on their balconies due to the lockdown restrictions.And it looks like the good weather will continue with temperatures to hit C and potentially C on the bank holiday this Friday which will mark the th anniversary of VE Day.According to the Met Office, todays weather will look rather cloudy in the west and north with brief brighter spells and further showers.Most parts of the UK will enjoy temperatures between C and C.On Friday the weather will be dry and warm with sunny spells with some scattered thunderstorms in the south.There will be rain in the far north, however, turning heavier as it spreads south with much colder weather following.Some leading bookmakers have even cut odds on this Friday to go down as the hottest ever May bank holiday.Corals PR Manager John Hill said: With temperatures set to rise over the new few days, we have slashed the odds on Friday being the hottest May bank holiday we have ever had in the UK.But over the weekend, temperatures are likely to turn bitterly-cold, forecasters warn, as Arctic air sweeps southwards across the whole of the country.BBCs Mr Taylor said: “Big temperature swings are not desperately unusual for this time of year, but certainly some big changes ahead later this week.“The next two days the warmth builds and Friday could see temperatures widely into the high teens and maybe C in the southeast corner.Through the weekend though, a surge of Arctic air s and some of you will struggle to get to double figures - even snow showers across the north and east of Scotland.UK meteorologists also confirmed that April  went down as the sunniest on record.The weather was a hit with Brits in lockdown as across the country people took to public parks to do their daily exercise.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: iraq parliament us backed prime minister government
story: Mustafa al-Kadhimi was sworn in as PM following weeks of tense political negotiations and the resignation of predecessor Adel Abdul Mahdi.Kadhimi was the third candidate chosen by the countrys fragmented political blocs after the previous two failed to get broad support.The security, stability and blossoming of Iraq is our path, Kadhimi wrote on Twitter after the vote.He becomes Iraq’s sixth premier since , ending five months of a leadership void.Abdul Mahdi had been leading a caretaker government when he stepped down last year.“This government came as a response to the social, economic and political crises our country is facing,” Kadhimi said as he addressed lawmakers.“It is a government that will provide solutions, not add to the crises.”He had to change his list of proposed ministers multiple times in the past week to satisfy the fragmented political blocs.The ex-intelligence chief is also a former journalist.Abdul Mahdi resigned last year as thousands of protesters took to the streets and demanded jobs and the ouster of the ruling elite.Iraqi officials say Kadhimi is acceptable to both the US and Iran.Negotiations are set to take place with the US next month.It was announced Wednesday that the US will grant a -day waiver for Iraq to continue importing electricity from Iran to help the new Iraqi government succeed.“In support of the new government the United States will move forward with a -day electricity waiver as a display of our desire to help provide the right conditions for success,” the State Department said in a statement on a call between Pompeo and Kadhimi.Relations between Iraq and the US suffered after an airstrike killed top Iranian general Qassim Soleimani in January.The new leader will immediately have multiple crises on his plate, including falling oil revenues and the coronavirus pandemic.The vacuum in leadership has left the country without an approved budget law. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un secret missile base coronavirus
story: Satellite images appear to show North Korea is constructing a giant storage and assembly area for its ballistic arsenal while the world is distracted by the coronavirus outbreak.The new base - close to Pyongyang’s main airport - includes underground storage areas and buildings tall enough to house the terrying Hwasong- intercontinental ballistic missile.The Sun Online has already reported how the rogue states dictator sees the mighty missile as a military game changer as it brings his enemies into range.According to new analysis by a Washington-based think tank the massive military site is likely to be finished by the end of this year or early next year.“While the preciseof the facility is unclear, its configuration and the size of its buildings and UGFindicate it can be used for the assembly of ballistic missiles from components delivered by rail from nearby factories,” said the Center for Strategic and International Studies.The reports author Joseph Bermudez said the Sil-li Ballistic Missile Support Facility could “accommodate all known and anticipated North Korean ballistic missiles and their . . . launchers [for] maintenance, storage of ballistic missiles and their transporters.”Its reported the site contains three large hangar-like buildings, one of which could accommodate the -foot Hwasong- in an upright position.It could also store the mobile “transporter-erector-launcher” or TEL on which the nuke can be moved around the country to make it more dficult to be targeted before it is launched.There are about  air defense bases and barracks within three miles of the base, - which is protected by ground-to-air missiles.When the Hwasong- was test fired in November , North Korean state media said it was a “new-type inter-continental ballistic rocket weaponry system capable of carrying super-heavy nuclear warhead and attacking the whole mainland of the US.”The satellite images of the site show the buildings are connected by a wide surfaced road network which could help move large trucks and ballistic missile launchers, reports the Times.They emerged just days after it was claimed Kim had been spotted at a fertilizer factory which some fear is a front for his weapons programme.During , North Korea and the US started a period of negotiations about Kims controversial nuclear ambitions which led to three separate meetings between Kim and President Trump.Before their first summit in Singapore, he agreed to suspend nuclear and ICBM testing, a promise that he has apparently kept until now.Those talks eventually failed due to Trump’s insistence on North Korean denuclearization and Kim’s demand for the removal of international sanctions.Earlier this year, Kim threatened to unleash a new strategic weapon in a New Years address railing against President Trump.He said his country was to end a moratorium on nuclear tests after what he called gangster-like demands by the United States.He said he would now look to secure a nuclear deterrent, and that the US would suffer helplessly in any conflict between the two countries.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk coronavirus lockdown futile hasnt saved lives
story: BRITAINS coronavirus lockdown was futile and hasnt saved any lives, leading experts have claimed.Researchers say that closing all non-essential businesses and ordering people to stay at home did little to reduce the number of Covid- cases across Europe.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut the scientists, from the University of East Anglia, found that closing schools and banning mass gatherings did work to slow the spread.Meanwhile, the expert behind Swedens coronavirus strategy claims Britains lockdown has been largely futile in containing the virus.It comes as Boris Johnson is set to unveil his long-awaited “unlockdown” plan on Sunday - to gradually end the nation’s virtual house arrest.The new study from UEA has revealed a potential blueprint for getting the UK out of lockdown.Researchers looked at the success of dferent social distancing measures across  European countries – in terms of how effective they have been at reducing the number of Covid- cases and deaths.They found that closing schools, banning mass gatherings and the closure of some non-essential business, particularly in the hospitality sector, were the most effective at stopping the spread of the disease.Enforcing the wearing of facemasks in public was not found to make an additional impact, they said.The study authors said that their research, which was funded by the National Institute for Health Research Health Protection Research Unit in Emergency Preparedness and Response at Kings College London and Public Health England, is experimental and it has not yet been peer-reviewed.But it is hoped that the findings could help policymakers decide the next steps for carefully lting Covid- lockdown measures.The researchers looked at the number of cases and deaths taken from daily published figures by the European Centre for Disease Control.These were compared with the start dates of dferent restrictions including banning mass gatherings, closing schools and businesses, stay at home orders, and wearing face masks.It showed that the measures have been effective in controlling the spread of Covid-, but not all interventions have been equally successful.Dr Julii Brainard, who also worked on the study, said: “We found that banning mass gatherings, closing some non-essential businesses, and closing educational facilities are most strongly associated with reduced incidence after a certain lag period.“But widespread closure of all non-essential businesses and stay-at-home policies do not appear to have had a signicant effect on the number of Covid- cases across Europe.”Meanwhile, Swedish researcher Dr Johan Giesecke has blasted Britains lockdown as futile.The epidemiologist, who advises the World Health Organisation, said the UK’s death toll suggested imposing social restriction measures is not the best method of tackling the pandemic.Sweden has not forced a lockdown, keeping open many schools, restaurants and businesses while the UK went into a complete shutdown on March .Yet the most recent figures show that more than  times as many Brits have died of Covid- than in Sweden where there has been fewer , fatalities.But the vast majority of the population have taken to voluntary social distancing as usage of public transport has dropped signicantly and large numbers are working from home.Referring to the high coronavirus death toll across UK care homes, Prof Giesecke said: “A hard lockdown does not protect old and frail people living in care homes - a population the lockdown was designed to protect”.He added: “Neither does it decrease mortality from Covid-, which is evident when comparing the UK’s experience with that of other European countries”.The academic argued Britains lockdown strategy “only pushes the severe cases into the future” and has not prevented them.He said: “There is very little we can do to prevent this spread: a lockdown might delay severe cases for a while, but once restrictions are eased, cases will reappear.”Despite resisting strict lockdown measures, Sweden’s Public Health Institute estimated that the country’s R number, the number of people each infected person passes the virus to, fell from . at the start of April to . at the end of the month.Professor Giesecke has previously been critical of the pandemic modelling produced by the Imperial College London team led by Professor Neil Ferguson.He suggested Professor Ferguson’s projected death tolls were too pessimistic and rejected suggestions that Sweden will see a mounting mortality rate, saying in a Swedish newspaper interview: “On the contrary, I think it will go down.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Tesla boss and his Canadian singer partner revealed the unusual moniker after announcing their baby news on social media this week.But the couple may not be able to get their child’s chosen name registered after hitting a legal hitch, TMZ reports.It is against the law in Calornia – where the baby was born – to include numbers or symbols in a name, according to a supervisor at the Department of Public Health Vital Records Office in Los Angeles.The law states names must only include the  letters of the English alphabet.But the name the new parents were apparently hoping for does not meet that criteria, having only two actual letters in it.Grimes, , a Canadian singer - whose real name is Claire Boucher - took to Twitter this week to apparently confirm their newborn would carry the name X Æ A-.She tweeted on Tuesday evening to explain, writing: X, the unknown iable.Æ, my elven spelling of Ai .A-  precursor to SR- . No weapons, no defenses, just speed. Great in battle, but non-violent + .When later asked about how the baby was doing, Musk told one curious fan X Æ A- was happy, healthy  cute as a button, followed by a smiley face.The bizarre name revelation came after the Tesla CEO, , posted a cute snap of their sleeping baby using a face tattoo filter, as well as one of him cradling the newborn at the hospital on Twitter.The South African tech mogul, who has five sons from his previous marriage, could be seen cuddling his infant son, who was swaddled in blankets.Earlier, when Elons followers pressed him for a name, he had apparently joked that the newborn is called X Æ A- Musk, which Grimes seemed to confirm.The name, which may be pronounced X-Ash-A, appeared to be partially inspired by one of the songs from her last album - ÆM.Grimes gave birth to their baby on Monday, with Elon announcing that mom and baby are all good.The Canadian native announced she was pregnant back in January with a photo in which a baby appeared to be superimposed on her stomach.She wrote: I thought about censoring them [her nipples] for a hot minute hahabut the photo is so much less feral without the nipples.Plus being knocked up is a very feral  war-like state of being. Might as well be what it is.It is Grimes first child, while Musk already has five children of his own - Nevada, Grfin, Kai, Xavier, Saxon, and Damien.The birth of their son coincides with Musk announcing in a series of bizarre tweets on Friday he would sell almost all of his physical possessions and will own no house.He admitted to his  million followers that Grimes is mad at him for selling off his stuff while she gives birth to their first child together.Elon - who has taken a pay cut amid the coronavirus crisis - appeared to send a caveat about the second home to future buyers on Twitter.Just one stipulation on sale: I own Gene Wilders old house. title: coronavirus eradicated by christmas
story: CORONAVIRUS could be eradicated in the UK by Christmas, one of the countrys top microbiologists said.Professor Hugh Pennington saidmass testing and contact tracing was ramped up Britain could be clear of COVID- by the holiday season.Emeritus Professor Pennington, from Aberdeen University, said the countries that have been rigorous in their efforts to trace new cases have been the most successful in flattening infection numbers - the UK could even get rid of coronavirus entirely by the end of the year.If we do a lot more testing and contact tracing by Christmas we could get it eradicated in the UK.That is what has happened in China and South Korea and New Zealand look like they have got there too.We could get this down to zero - or near zero - by Christmas. If China can do it we can.The Government is trialling a contact tracing app in the Isle of Wight, with plans to roll it out to the rest of the country.Professor Pennington said the UK should have focused on tracing new cases from the start of the outbreak.He said: I would give the UK and Scottish governments five out of ten over the way they have handled this.The big mistake was on March  when they decided the policy was to just flatten the curve and give up mass testing and contact tracing.The policy was taken, it seems to me, because of a lack of testing capacity and it was wrong. I think it was a bad policy judgement.They could have used university labs, more NHS labs and others much sooner.Professor Pennington said the levels of new cases in the UK needed to be ten times lower to make a meaningful dference.Yesterday there were , new cases of the virus - but the Government has been quick to explain case numbers are higher because of higher numbers of testing.Professor Pennington said: At the moment we are past the peak, but not on a signicantly downward trend, the virus is at a sort of a plateau just below the peak.He said one of the biggest problems facing the UK over the next few months would be people coming into the country.Heathrow Airport are currently trialing thermal imaging cameras to check passengers for coronavirus.Heathrow boss John Holland-Kaye said yesterday the UK needed to work on an international common standard of coronavirus screening to allow the aviation sector to get back on its feet - and to keep new cases out.But Professor Pennington was not convinced screening measures were enough.He said: I am sceptical this will work well enough because you will miss half of those infected because of theperiod of the virus when people may not be showing symptoms.And he added: We also cant wait for a vaccine. title: kate middleton this morning photo project
story: KATE Middleton revealed Prince Louis rainbow photoshoot left her covered in paint as she launched her new photography project on This Morning.The Duchess of Cambridge spoke to Holly and Phil about Hold Still which she hopes will capture the spirit of the nation during the coronavirus outbreak.During the interview, the mum-of-three spoke of some of her own most recent portraits - including those she took of Prince Louis to mark his second birthday.Speaking of the photos, in which the tot grins at the camera while smearing paint over his face, Kate revealed: Luckily that wasnt documented but I looked like Louis at the end of those!The Duchess also opened up about the challenges she has faced while homeschooling three children of dferent ages.She told Holly: George gets very upset because he just wants to do all of Charlotte’s projects - making sort of spider sandwiches is far cooler than doing literacy work.The mum added that its been dficult to explain to George, six, Charlotte, five, and Louis, two, whats going on in the world - but that FaceTime is keeping them in touch with the rest of the family.We hadnt done a huge amount of FaceTime and face calls but obviously we are doing that a lot more now, she revealed.And actually its been really great, we try and check in daily with family members and speak to them about news and things like that.And in a lot of ways weve got a lot more contact, a lot more face time than perhaps we would have had before. But it is dficult, its hard to explain to a five and a six, nearly seven-year-old what’s going on.With the UK in its seventh week of lockdown, Kate wants Brits to reflect the resilience, bravery and kindness they are experiencing by capturing family, friends and colleagues living under lockdown.Her new initiative, Hold Still, is being run with the National Portrait Gallery which the duchess supports as patron.Of her own photography skills, she told This Morning: Im very much an amateur photographer - I sort of learn along the way but during this time I’ve spent lots of time bringing out my camera and taking lots of photographs of the children because they are always around us and we are doing stuff together which has been great.Speaking about her new project, Kate said: Weve all been struck by some of the incredible images weve seen which have given us an insight into the experiences and stories of people across the country.Some desperately sad images showing the human tragedy of this pandemic and other uplting pictures showing people coming together to support those more vulnerable.Hold Still aims to capture a portrait of the nation, the spirit of the nation, what everyone is going through at this time. Photographs reflecting resilience, bravery, kindness - all those things that people are experiencing.Kate has been struck by some of the striking photos taken of le at the moment, including an image of two self-isolating grandparents putting their hands up to glass doors to touch the fingers of their grandchildren on the other side.Another picture to strike a chord was a nurse showing the red marks and bruising on her face after wearing personal protective equipment during a -hour sht.The project, which is free and open to all ages and abilities, includes three categories - Helpers And Heroes, Your New Normal and Acts Of Kindness.The duchess will help to curate  of the entries, chosen for the emotion or experiences they express rather then their expertise, with the photographs going on virtual display before a selection are shown across the UK later in the year.The project opens from Thursday and runs until June , with photographers asked to send their pictures via the National Portrait Gallerys website.We are backing a proposal by Lord Ashcroft to honour our health heroes with the gallantry gong given for acts of bravery that did not take place in battle.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.

title: garden centres reopen uk
story: Nurseries across the country had to close on March  to comply with instructions for the shutdown of all non-essential facilities.Lockdown restrictions could be eased for garden centres, making way for them to be one of the first non-essential retailers to open their doors under new guidelines.With their big open air spaces, costumers believe it will be dficult for coronavirus to spread.A YouGov poll showed  per cent of people who took part felt comfortable about garden centres reopening.Some have already begun operations including Plants Galore which did not close its doors during the title: schools reopening social distancing
story: WITH reports the Government is considering reopening some of the UKs schools in June, many parents will be wondering how headteachers will enforce stringent social distancing.Its understood students aged between four and  willto class first, followed by Year  and  pupils. Heres what we know so far.Boris Johnson is to reveal his road map out of lockdown on Sunday - and hes expected to address when schools will .However, the Government is reportedly hoping pupils will be able toto classes in June - although nine out of ten parents say they would be unhappy with schools reopening soon after lockdown is eased.When students do go back, there are likely to be some big changes inside classrooms.For example, class sizes may be reduced.This is one of the measures now adopted in schools across Europe as they begin to reopen.Pupils have recently ed to schools in Wuhan, where coronavirus first took hold.Many of the schools that are now open in the area have restricted the number of pupils allowed into classrooms in order to ensure there can be adequate social distancing.This currently seems very unlikely.At the moment, its understood primary schools willfirst, followed by Year  and  pupils, who willto secondaries during a staggered recall.Ofsted chief Amanda Spielman says there is a “great deal of logic” in first moving younger kids back into the classroom first.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - and youngsters were taught how to practise social distancing.When youngstersin the UK, its likely similar measures will be followed.This isnt yet something the Government has offered specic guidance on.However, its a definite possibility.Adult Brits are going to be told theyll need to cover their faces in some workplaces and on public transport, and officials are stockpiling masks for the purpose.Countries around the world are largely insisting children wear masks.In France, secondary school children canto school in May - but onlythey wear a mask.The Government has so far issued very specic guidance about school meals on its website, although the issue has not yet been addressed for pupils ing to class.Under normal circumstances, schools are not expected to provide free school meals to eligible children who are not attending due to illness orthe school is closed.However, during the pandemic, schools are expected to continue providing support.Officials also say schools open for the vulnerable children, as well as key workers children, should provide meal options for staff and youngsters, as well as free schools meals for eligible pupils.Families in need can also apply for vouchers for major supermarkets through the gov.uk website.There was a suggestion in April that this was a possibility - but Ofsted chief Amanda Speilman has since claried its extraordinarily unlikely.Ms Speilman said that there will still be some children who will likely be schooled at homethey have family members who are vulnerable.She told Sky News Sophy Ridge show: Given that there will be substantial numbers of children in households where somebody is at high risk, I think it is extraordinarily unlikely that anybody would start at the stick end of the spectrum rather than the carrot.Matt Hancock had earlier refused to comment on whether those who decide not to send their children in may face fines.

title: uk lockdown formally extended cabinet
story: BRITAINS lockdown will be formally extended today after another review of the measures.Boris Johnson held his Cabinet for a crunch meeting today, who have to by law look at the coronavirus lockdown measures once again.Dominic Raab is expected to reveal at tonights press conference that nothing will change in the next few days.And he will tip the public to watch Boris Johnsons address to the nation on Sunday for more new information.The PM said yesterday that he will speak at the weekend about the future measures, with the hope of changing some as early as Monday.The Government will continue getting all the latest scientic information over the weekend before making any changes.Another Cabinet meeting may also take place beforehand.The PM will address the nation on Sunday at pm, expected to be in a video message similar to the one he released when he announced the lockdown on March .And more information on what exactly that will mean will come in the next few days.The Sun revealed today that Brits are set to be told they can go out to exercise as much as they want, and to be allowed to go to sunbathe in parks from next week.No major changes to the nationwide lockdown are expected, however.But this afternoon Scotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said that the controls will continue to stay strict north of the border.She confirmed another three weeks of lockdown, and insisted it was too soon to consider any measures to be eased.And Wales - which also has a higher rate of infection than England - will also stick closely to the lockdown rules.It means the measures will likely be dferent from next week in England - compared to Scotland and Wales, and will risk confusing the public.Devolved countries technically have the power over health matters in their own areas.Downing Street has said it wanted all countries to move as one in and out of the lockdown.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: sturgeon lockdown extended catastrophic
story: Scotland First Minister revealed the lockdown would continue north of the border despite Boris preparing to announce the lting of some measures on Sunday.Speaking at her daily press conference, Ms Sturgeon slammed reports the Uk Government was set to ditch the Stay at Home message,  with the PM set to ease restrictions as soon as Monday.She said:“The other possible changes reported in the media today - such as encouraging more people back to work now or opening beer gardens or encouraging more use of public transport - would not, in my judgement, be safe for us to make yet.And I exercise from Monday.Cafes could re-open and outdoor spaces soon after, and park picnics may also be on again, as long as people stay two metres apart.It comes as Boris Johnson was tipped to ditch Britains Stay at Home message as he prepares to ease the UKs lockdown measures next week.The PM will address the nation on Sunday with a roadmap for how to tweak the current lockdown measures, some of which may come into effect the very next day.The news came as:The Scottish leader insisted all the evidence pointed towards having to continue with the same rules.She explained: “Our assessment of the evidence leads me to conclude that the lockdown must be extended at this stage.“We know that progress remains fragile, our estimates suggest there are still signicant amounts of people in Scotland infected with this virus.Any signicant easing of restrictions at this stage would be very very risky indeed.The PM will meet with Sturgeon and the other devolved administration leaders later this afternoon.Ahead of the meeting, the SNP leader insisted she will not be pressured into lting restrictions early.She said: If the PM wants to decide to move at a faster rate than Scotland that is his right.I hope you understand and agree that I must make judgements informed by the evidence that are right and safe for Scotland.I will not be pressured into lting restrictions prematurely. px,px, px" title: hayfever may be in the mind
story: A new study found that some people suffer from allergic reactions even when there is no pollen in the air and that they could in fact be having placebo responses.The study, published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in the US, suggests that someones symptoms might be caused by being in a place where they have previously been exposed to pollen.Dr Luciana Besedovsky, from Hard Medical School and the University of Tübingen, said an allergic response can be triggered even in the absence of allergens by simply reencountering the environmental context in which an allergen was previously administered.For the study, researchers recruited  men and administered triggers such as birch pollen and grass - all common allergies for people who suffer from hayfever - through a nasal spray.To determine whether their reactions were genuine or in fact part of a placebo effect, the group were asked toand carry out the experiment again.However, this time they were given a harmless nasal spray of salt water, but were told that there was a  per cent chance that it contained pollen.For some, simply being in the same room where they had originally been exposed to pollen did spur a reaction.Experts noted a rise in an enzyme known as tryptase, which is produced at a higher level during hay fever as the immune system kicks in.They then wanted to test whether a similar reaction could be triggered by a smell.The group were asked to snf an almond-scented chemical before being blasted with pollen.Scientists then asked them to repeat the experiment again at a later stage and noted that the scent triggered mild hay fever symptoms, such as sneezing, in some - even though there was no pollen around anymore.Dr Besedovsky, first author of the study, said: Our findings suggestsomeone goes to a place where they usually have hayfever, like a park with lots of trees, they might have an allergic reaction.This might happen outside of pollen season because they have been mentally conditioned to associate that park with hayfever.She added that while she is not claiming that people with hayfever make up the condition, it’s clear that there is a clear link between how the immune system responds to certain cues from the body.The academic also suspected that sleep may help people store a memory which links an allergic reaction to a place.To test this theory, half of the participants were asked to stay awake all night after the first experiment.For those who had a good nights sleep, their tryptase levels only rose the second time after originally being exposed to the pollen.However, most of the group had a rise in the enzyme when smelling the almond-scented chemical - regardless of whether or not they had slept.Dr Besedovsky said: These findings have important implications for understanding the often observed placebo allergic responses occurring in the absence of allergens.In conclusion to her findings, she said that sleep may actually be a contributor to the aggregation of allergies.All participants enrolled in the test were not found to have any sleep disturbances before they began the trial.She stated that people may have been mentally conditioned to associate a park with hayfever, therefore spurring on symptoms.In the UK, around  million people are affected by hay fever with the pollen seasons typically kicking off in late March or early April.The pollen count for this week across most of the county is at a moderate level, except in the north and Scotland where some areas will see high pollen concentrations.Meanwhile, as the coronavirus pandemic in the UK continues, hayfever sufferers have also been growing concerned about their symptoms, some of which can be mistaken for the virus.The two main symptoms of coronavirus are a high fever and a new continuous cough, whereas people suffering with hayfever will not have a high temperature and will not usually have aches and pains, another symptom of the virus.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsKeir Starmer admits Jeremy Corbyns leadership was number one issue in election defeatThe new Labour leader was reluctant to criticise his predecessor during the campaign to succeed Jeremy Corbyn who remained popular among the party membershipShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. During his time as the partyaposs Brexit spokesperson and in the leadership campaign Mr Starmer was reluctant to criticise Mr Corbyn - who remained extremely popular among the partyaposs membership.But in an interview with the Financial Times, Mr Starmer, who won the leadership on a landslide, said Mr Corbyn was the main issue which came up when he went to more than  constituencies where he knocked on doors and spoke to campaign teams.“The topic of conversation was always what was coming up . . . anybody who knocks on doors knows a number of things came up,” he said. “The leadership of Labour party was number one, fair or unfair,” Sir Keir told the FT Magazine.Mr Starmer said the partyaposs programme for government was also an issue with voters turned off by the “overload” of Labour’s manesto. This was a common complaint at the time with many MPs who said that the electorate saw the plan - which included proposals to nationalise several industries, hand £bn of shares to workers, and plans for an extra £bn a year of tax and spending - was unworkable.  “People thought there was too much in it and because there was too much in it they didn’t believe any of it,” Mr Starmer told the FT.  Mr Starmer has already distanced himself from the previous administration by sacking a number of those close to Jeremy Corbyn including Ian Lavery and Jon Trickett and instead promoting those on the so-called soft left. But policy-wise so far the sht is more subtle with hints at a more social democratic rather than purely socialist agenda despite the retention of some of the radical language of the Corbyn era. He told the FT: The levels of inequality . . . are now so deeply ingrained that only transformative change is going to do something about it.From the coronavirus to Brexit, this is an era of great change and uncertainty. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has been in lockdown for six weeks. Hundreds of people are still dying each day from coronavirus. But now that weaposre past the peak, Boris Johnson will lay out a roadmap on Sunday  May for how lockdown will be eased. He will change very little immediately - and wonapost end lockdown in one go. But some changes will take effect from Monday  Maypossible. And in the long term, his plan will give us a clearer picture of what the UK will look like over the coming months in a new, coronavirus-scarred world. The Mirror understands a draft -page plan has been drawn up to get the country back to normal. The Governmentaposs blueprint aims to to relax the lockdown in staggered steps between now and October.  Schools and outdoor activities are set to resume within weeks, while pubs and restaurants look doomed to stay closed for months. Meanwhile the furlough scheme will be wound down after June, fines for breaching lockdown will rise, and you could be told to cover your face in public. So what will reopen, what will stay shut - and how will your everyday le change  Weaposve explained the timeline and all the main proposals below.for the Mirror Politics newsletter at www.mirror email -at .am to navigate the day ahead.When will lockdown end  The Prime Minister will lay out his roadmap for ending lockdown on Sunday  May. He will give an address to the nation at pm, with more details and a Parliamentary statement to follow on Monday. Some measures will be lted as early as Monday  Maywe possibly can. But lockdown will not end all in one go. Immediate measures on Monday are likely to be only very minor and we donapost know yet what theyaposll be. Experts say some closures or social distancing will last until , when weaposre likely to have a vaccine. Cabinet minister Michael Gove warned: Ultimately, unless and until we have a vaccine, then I suspect we’re going to have to live with some degree of constraint because of the nature of the virus. Meanwhile, the legal date to review the lockdown is Thursday  May. That review will keep restrictions in place - but no detail will be announced on that day.  Will we be given specic dates  This seems unlikely. The Irish government has spelt out five phases each with a target date between May and August. But while Downing Street hasnapost denied using phases, they probably wonapost have a specic date. Instead Boris Johnson’s spokesman said: “What we’ll have to do as we make changes is monitor the impact those changes are having upon the R rate in particular. “And once we have that information, we’ll obviously be able to judgeand when we’re in a position to go further.”  What are the proposed dates  According to a draft plan seen by the Mirror, from the start of June, primary schools in England would have a phased . Households could also be allowed to expand their “social bubble” to one other household of family or friends. At the end of June, secondary schools would , some outdoor activities and cafes. Then, pubs and restaurants could reopen at the end of August or early September. The final stage of lting restrictions, which could include the opening of gyms and and theof fans to Premier League matches, is the least predictable. Earmarked for October, it is being fiercely debated, amid fears of a second wave of Covid- or a flu outbreak. The Sun reports gyms face being closed for most of , while playgrounds are also poised to stay shut. . From Monday Unlimited exercise allowed. Employees to be encouraged toto workplaces that have stayed open through- out the lockdownsafe. Garden centres could reopen while there may be more guidance on the use of outdoor spaces including open-air markets, high streets and cemeteries. . End of May Start of June Phasedof primary schools in England, starting with Year . Households could be allowed to expand “social bubble” to meet one other household of family or friends. . JunePhasedof secondary schools in England before the summer holidays. Small team sports such as five-a-side football could be allowed, along with outdoor gatherings of fewer than  people. Cafes with outdoor seating could reopen while outdoor sports like golf, tennis and angling might resume. Possibleof Premier League matches, although behind closed doors. . End of August Start of September Pubs, bars and restaurants could gradually reopen although customers would be expected to follow strict social distancing rules. . October Possibleof football fans to matches. Gyms could be allowed to re-open. But any further lting of restrictions to get back to normal le would be in doubt amid fears of a second wave of coronavirus or an outbreak of seasonal flu. What will the roadmap talk about  It will spell out how the lockdown changes in phases over time. It may have a traffic light system spelling out what you can and canapost do as restrictions lt. The plan would also drop the governmentaposs stay at home branding in favour of a more subtle message. But it will also make clear that the UK is not ing to business as usual. Some restrictions will be eased, but others - like fines for breaches - will be made harsher than they are now. While people are put back on public transport and in some workplaces, there will be strict social distancing to keep people two metres apart. People are likely to be advised to cover their faces, and will be told to use an NHS phone app that alerts youyouaposve come into close contact with the virus.  How does the R number, apostest, track and traceapos and five tests come into all this  The aposRapos number is the average number of people infected by each Covid- carrier. It has to be low enough for each stage of the roadmap to begin. Currently R is between . and . because so many people are out of contact with each other. Every time you relax a lockdown rule, R rises again. Ministers say they wonapost do anything that pushes the R number back above . The UK must also pass five tests before easing lockdown:The NHS is able to cope A sustained fall in deaths New infections dropping enough Adequate testing and PPE No risk of a second peak that overwhelms NHSTo help pass all these tests there is a apostest, track and traceapos strategy planned for launch at the middle of May. It will mean downloading an NHS app which tells youyouaposve been near a Covid- carrier - and ensuring you isolate quicklyyouaposre put at risk to stop it spreading further. More on this below. So what will the plan say   Schools Schools will reopen in a phased way - with some year groups likely to go back first while others are told to remain at home. Boris Johnson has signalled he wants primary schools to be the first to , and it is likely that Year  will be the first to . Years  and  would then be the first back in secondary schools, according to one plan. Priority could also be put on pupils with special educational needs. Teachers need time to put social distancing in place, including reorganising classrooms to keep children  metres apart. Sources suggest this will begin as early as June . No declined to sayall pupils will be back before September. Universities Arts students will be the last to , with students of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science prioritised in the autumn, according to the Sunday Times. Thirty-three universities are working on a contingency plan to fast-track students of the key sciences back to campus.  Public transport The number of trains will slowly rise as lockdown eases, to avoid overcrowding. Hand sanitiser and one-way systems would be placed on the network, with spacing at s and bus stops “clearly marked out” to keep people two metres apart. New timetables will be introduced as planned in May, even though trains will not run to them straight away. Firms would be urged to stagger workersapos start times to spread out the rush out. But London mayor Sadiq Khan has warned capacity could be overwhelmed. A double decker London bus would have to have just  passengers. Meanwhile the government has hinted at more support for Cycle to Work, a tax break scheme where you can buy a bicycle over a year through your employer.  Workplaces and working from home Workplaces would have floor markings to ensure people are two metres apart, according leaked draft guidance. The guidance could also recommend staggered arrival times and breaks, fewer people in lts and regular deep cleaning. According to BuzzFeed News, other draft measures for workplaces include:Providing additional parking or bike racks Having more entrances into the workplace Alternatives to touch-based security devices such as keypads Washing unorms on site rather than at home Reducing maximum occupancy for lts, providing hand sanitiser for the operation of lts and encouraging use of stairs Introducing more one-way flow routes through buildings Reviewing layouts to allow staff to work further apart from each otherBut workers would in some cases be allowed to sit less than two metres apart - despite the risk being  to  times higher at one metre than two metres. Not all workers would go back to the officethey donapost need to. Government advisors have previously said working from home could become the new normal until thereaposs a vaccine for coronavirus.The furlough scheme At the moment, .m workers are having their wages paid by the state - up to % or £, a month. Chancellor Rishi Sunak has warned this is not sustainable because it costs as much as the NHS. The furlough scheme runs in full up to the end of June and will then be wound down. Officials appear to be looking at cutting the amount to workers and the self-employed or limiting it only to certain sectors. This has sparked fears some will lose out. The future of the furlough scheme wonapost be announced on Sunday. Sources said it would be in the week or two weeks after the PMaposs address on Sunday. Picnics, golf course, tennis and going outdoors People will be allowed to exercise more than once a day, drive to the countryside and have picnics, according to the Mail on Sunday. And the Daily Mail claims golf courses, tennis courts and fishing lakes will reopen from June too. Youaposd still have to be with members of your own household only, and keep two metres away from other groups.  No has not confirmed these reports. But ministers and scientists have repeatedly said outdoor activities are less risky than those indoors - indicating theyaposll be the first to be allowed back.  Supermarkets Supermarkets would doubtless keep many of the social distancing measures theyaposve already put in place. And opening hours could be increased on Sunday to reduce overcrowding. Boris Johnson has said heaposs looking at relaxing Sunday trading laws to reduce queues on the weekend.  Building sites Building sites were never told to close under lockdown guidance - as long as two metres could be kept between workers. So the government is expected to make a renewed push for people toto work there. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said because the risk of the virus outdoors is lower than indoors, there’s “more scope” for some jobs outside. He added: “Thereaposs more scope for people ing to work on building sites for example, or more outdoor leisure activities than is likely to be the case for indoor ones.”  aposBubblesapos of up to  people People could meet small bubbles of their friends and family under one idea to ease the coronavirus lockdown. Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish government was looking at the proposal as one possible way to relax restrictions on peopleaposs movement in the future. But she warnedthe idea does happen, itaposs got to be the same people day-to-day, week-to-week to prevent Covid- being passed on more widely. That means people would have to choose one bubble of friends or family - and stick with them, while continuing not to meet other people they love. Reports later said the idea was one being mulled by the UK government. But itaposs not set in stone.  Fines for breaching lockdown The government is considering raising the penalty for defying lockdown from £ to £ for a first offence. The fines would then double for each offence after that, just as they do already. And the maximum fine would rise from just under £, at the moment to £,. A senior government source did not deny these figures, reported by the Sunday , were under consideration. Covering your face The government hasnapost made a final decision on whether to ask people to cover their face in public. However, some kind of face covering advice is widely expected after Boris Johnson covering oneaposs face in some situations would be a useful tool. Itaposs understood thatface coverings are required, they wonapost be masks. The government doesnapost want to cause a shortage in personal protective equipment that should be available to the NHS. But coverings like a scarf could be recommended. And the government would provide guidance on what kind of material you can make such a covering from. Itaposs important that people donapost end up fiddling with their face covering in a way that means theyaposre actually creating more risk, by continually touching their face.  Using a new app A new contact tracing app is expected to launch in around mid-May after trials on the Isle of Wight this week. The app, which is voluntary, will use Bluetooth to track when people have come into close contact with someone who, now or later, tests positive for coronavirus. It will urge someone who’s been in contact with a virus carrier to get tested and to isolate themselvesnecessary. It is part of the crucial “test, track and trace” strategy that is needed before the UK-wide lockdown can be relaxed. The idea is that this would allow society to partially reopen while keeping the virus at bay and sick people in isolation. For it to work properly, at least % or so of the population need to download it. It will be paired with an army of , human contact tracers to follow up on those who need further attention, or those who don’t download the app.  Arriving in the UK Ministers are actively looking at quarantining people who arrive into the UK once lockdown begins to ease. Nothing is confirmed, but reports have suggested people will be asked to isolate themselves for two weeks. If so, this would be a major blow to the airline industry and render most holidays to Britain pointless. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps told the BBC: I think it’s important... that we ensure the sacrices in the sense of social distancing that we’re asking the British people to make are matched by anybody who comes to this country. So I am actively looking at these issues right now. So that when we have infection rates within the country under control, weaposre not importing. Local lockdowns The government is considering new wave of local lockdown restrictions later this year to stop new spikes of coronavirus in their tracks. At the moment, officials are focused on easing the lockdown at the same pace across the UK - to move as one nation in the Covid- crisis. But itaposs understood officials are looking at changing that approachthere is a rapid new second outbreak of the virus, which needs quick action to be halted. A government source said: If you were to see worrying increases of transmission happening in regions, then you would want to move quickly to try and stop those.  Pubs, grassroots sport, mass gatherings and other venues Pubs will be the last places to reopen as lockdown is eased, the Government has confirmed. Likewise, ministers have indicated that mass gatherings will be among the last things to reopen. But some local cricket and grassroots football could– as long as spectators can stay in the open air. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries said: “Outdoor environments are safer. Butyou go with a load of friends and sit in a pub… that’s not a good thing to do.” And Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick told the No coronavirus update: “Transmission is signicantly less outdoors than indoors.” Meanwhile hairdressers and nail bars could remain shut for six months, sources told The Sun. Courts Courts might have to use two courtrooms where we would have used one in the past, so that jurors can retire into a safe space and also be spaced out and distanced within the court. People are also measuring courtrooms - often a cramped environment - to work out what would be safe. And the number of people on juries could be reduced. A aposone UKapos approach Scotland and Wales have repeatedly set out plans ahead of, or slightly dferently to, the rest of the UK government. And itaposs true that the Scottish and Welsh governments have control over areas like schools and care homes. However, ministers have also stressed they want to keep the whole of the UK moving in the same way at the same time. And the government has distanced itself from claims that worst-hit regions, like London and the West Midlands, could have dferent rules to the countryside. NHS services Some routine operations and fertility treatment have already been restored as hospital inpatients fall for several weeks in a row. However, itaposs not yet clear when other services - including ENT therapies and dentistry, where staff are particularly at risk of transmission - will continue.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFears members of the French Army could have been infected with covid- back in October after competing at the World Military Games, have been called completely plausible, by an infectious disease expert. The French Army has denied any of its athletes were contaminated at the event held in Wuhan, China, which has since been declared as the epicentre of the pandemic. Reacting to the revelations from numerous French athletes that they ed from the World Military Games with a mystery illness, the French Ministry of the Armed Forces told the countryaposs media as the epidemic linked to Covid- was not known at the time. They added that the French delegation, made up of  people including  athletes benefited from medical checks before and during the games with a dedicated medical team made up of about  people. It said there were declared cases with the army health service of flu or of hospitalisations during or after ing from the games that could be linked, to cases of covid-.to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at  mirror email  -after the press conference every evening.   Athletes at the World Military Games in coronavirus epicentre Wuhan last October have also been quoted in French media as speculating that they may have brought the virus back home with them. This revelation came after it was discovered that a Frenchman, Amirouche Hammar, , had been infected with the coronavirus in the Paris region as early as December . French media reported that investigations into the origins of the coronavirus revealed there is a possibility it emerged in Wuhan as early as October  when the games took place. A French delegation took part in the th edition of the World Military Games in Wuhan from October  to  - just  days before the first Chinese person officially became ill with coronavirus. There were more than , athletes from all over the world taking part. According to French news channel BFMTV, a number of athletes ed to France with unusual symptoms, including fevers and body aches. The news channel says none of the ing athletes were tested and the French Army, who were responsible for organising their athletes at the military games, reportedly confirmed that they had not wanted to test any athletes either. BFMTV quotes one athlete, who preferred to remain anonymous, as saying that he originally thought he had simply caught a cold.  However, when news began to emerge of an epidemic in Wuhan, many athletes on a WhatsApp group reportedly began to openly wonderit was possible that they had contracted the disease too. Now that it has been revealed that Amirouche Hammar in France had the coronavirus back in December, closer attention is being paid to what these athletes have said. Local media notes that Elodie Clouvel, a world champion modern pentathlete, was asked on local TV channel Television Loire  on March ,she was worried about the prospect of potentially having to spend the summer in Japan for the Olympics. She replied: No because I think that with Velentin [her partner] we have already had the coronavirus, well the covid-. The -year-old added: We were in Wuhan for the World Military Games at the end of October. And afterwards, we all fell ill. Valentin missed three days of training. Me, I was sick too. I had things I had never had before. We werenapost particularly worried because no one was talking about it yet.  She added: A lot of athletes at the World Military Games were very ill. We were recently in touch with a military doctor who told us: aposI think you had it because a lot of people from this delegation were ill.apos Local media report that since she spoke up on March , many athletes have been asked not to answer questions from journalists and to refer media enquiries to the head of communication of the French armies. According to French media, athletes who were in Wuhan reportedly received telephone calls from the army a few weeks ago to reassure them. One of these athletes, who remains anonymous, is quoted as saying: We were told, there is no risk, you left on October , and the virus arrived on November . French media report that sick athletes were also noted in some other delegations, including the Swedish delegation, with people ing to Sweden with strong fevers. But some athletes are sceptical, with Aloise Ratornaz, silver medallist in sailing, telling Ouest-France: I do not think there were any signicant risks of being infected. We lived in isolation during these world games. We had a whole village just for the athletes. She added: We had a restaurant for the athletes where all the food was completely filtered, controlled, in a completely sanitised atmosphere. Professor Eric Caumes, an infectious and tropical disease specialist at the Pitie-Salpetriere hospital in Paris, said the theory that athletes participating in the World Military Games in Wuhan were contaminated with covid- is completely plausible. Despite the French army strenuously contesting the allegations, prof Caumes has subsequently been quoted in French media as saying that the characteristics of the illness and the symptoms that have been described by the athletes make one think that it is covid-. Caumes added: You saw that in France, we had our first official case end January. Then a few days ago, we realised that the first French case actually appeared at the end of December at the Bondy hospital. And we will no doubt find other cases from December. So Iaposm not very surprised that exactly the same thing happened in Wuhan.

story: NewsHalf of all UK rubbish tips to open next week amid lockdown fly-tipping concernsMany household recycling and waste centres were closed when the country went into lockdown, due to dficulties with social distancing and so councils could concentrate staff and resources on bin collectionsShareCommentsByEmily Beament:,  MAY NewsQueues for the tip at Bidston Recycling Centre, Birkenhead, as people flock to dump their lockdown rubbish " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHalf of all UK rubbish tips are to open next week amid fly-tipping concerns during lockdown, a survey of local authorities suggests. According to the Association of Directors of Environment, Economy, Planning and Transportfound more than four in fiveresponding English councils had plans to open some dumps. About % of local authorities planning to have household waste and recycling centres open this week and a further % expected to reopen sites by May , the survey conducted last week reveals. Many household recycling and waste centres were closed when the country went into lockdown, due to dficulties with social distancing and so councils could concentrate staff and resources on bin collections. But closure of tips and curbs on some collections, along with more waste being generated by people embarking on spring clean clear-outs, DIY projects and gardening, has raised concerns over an increase in fly-tipping.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereThis week, the Government published updated guidance encouraging local authorities to reopen their centressocial distancing measures can be put in place and staff and visitors can be kept safe. Householders are being told they should only take rubbish to a household waste and recycling centreit cannot be stored safely at home and no alternatives for disposing of it, such as bulky waste collections, are available. David Renard, environment spokesman for the Local Government Association, said: Councils are keen to open household waste and recycling centres as soon as practicable. The decision to reopen sites will be taken by inidual councils based on risk assessments in their area. This will be a gradual process over the next few weeks and based on whether they have enough staff, social distancing measures are in place to protect workers and members of the public, and waste staff are given personal protective equipment to reduce the risk of infection and provide reassurance. Last week, Waste facilities in Manchester opened for the first time in weeks - with huge queues of drivers waiting to dump rubbish. It follows a surge in flytipping since Brits were told they must stay at home. Local Government Secretary Robert Jenrick has said councils should be confident to reopen tips as soon as possible - although there have been warnings that protective equipment for waste workers needs to be provided.  At the waste centre on Reliance Street in Manchester a queue of cars was already waiting by .am, half an hour before it was scheduled to open. Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham said: While we are reopening centres, this is not ato normal. We would ask the public to limit their journeys and only travel to a household waste and recycling centreit is absolutely essential to do so.

story: NewsKate Middleton shares powerful photos that capture nations mood in coronavirus crisisThe Duchess of Cambridge, herself a keen photographer, wants the public to share photos representing three themes - Helpers and Heroes, Your New Normal and Acts of KindnessShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsKate Middleton is calling on photographers to capture the nations mood" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge wants the public to share their photos which capture the nation’s mood during the Covid crisis. Accomplished amateur snapper Kate has chosen five images she believes represent photography project Hold Still’s three core themes – Helpers and Heroes, Your New Normal and Acts of Kindness. She said: “We’ve all been struck by some of the incredible images we’ve seen which have given us an insight into the experiences and stories of people across the country. “Hold Still aims to capture a portrait of the nation, the spirit of the nation, what everyone is going through. “Photographs reflecting resilience, bravery, kindness – all those things that people are experiencing.” to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror emailKate’s choices include a heartbreaking shot of intensive care nurse Aimee Gould’s face covered in red marks from PPE after a -hour sht treating sick patients at Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospital. Aimee, who shared the selfie online, wrote: “This is the face going through hell. This is the face full of pressure damage from wearing PPE for almost  hours a day. This is the face of someone who hasn’t seen their own family for nearly a month. “This is the face of someone who holds your dying family member’s hand, so they’re never alone.” Another snap shows Ray and Theresa Cossey, both , in lockdown in Norfolk and their great-grandchildren Florence, three, and Edith, one, trying to touch them through glass. The moving snap was shared on Twitter by ITV weatherman Chris Page, who wrote: “This is the most adorable thing I’ve seen so far today from a friend of mine!”Another of the Duchess’s choices is a sweet picture which was posted by West Midlands Ambulance Service showing an adorable five-year-old called Eadee with her face covered in multi-coloured paint. Her mum Katie said “she wanted to be a rainbow in the shape of a love heart” to thank brave NHS workers.  Kate also selected images of Jack Dodsley, , dancing with a worker dressed in a protective mask at Newfield Nursing Home, Sheffield, and a masked worker carrying NHS scrubs being made last month in a manufacturing site in North London. Hold Still is being run in conjunction with the National Portrait Gallery, which Kate is a patron of.She will launch the project on ITV’s This Morning today and submissions can be made via npg.org.uk.Images can be from phones or cameras and each will be assessed on the emotion and experience it conveys rather than its photographic quality or technical expertise.  Participants are encouraged to write a short statement describing why their photograph should be selected for display. The closing date for entries is June . The top  will be part of a final exhibition which will be released digitally at first and potentially become a physical exhibition in the future. Kate, , is a confident and skilled photographer, regularly releasing her own photographs to mark her children’s birthdays in recent years. A senior palace source said: “The Duchess has been inspired by many of the amazing feats accomplished by so many people that have brought Britain together. “The aim of the project is to bring together an unofficial national archive of the crisis, what has touched our everyday lives, the heroes behind the stories and images. “The Duchess’s choices merely act as inspiration for the categories – anyone can enter and the aim is to get as many people involved as possible. “The hope is it will create a unique photographic portrait of the people of our nation as we hold still for the good of others, and celebrate those who have continued so we can stay safe.” Kensington Palace said the aim was to “capture the spirit, the mood, the hopes, the fears and the feelings of the nation as we continue to deal with the outbreak”.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhen Gillian Haywood set off to take her friendaposs dog Eli for a walk she had no idea she wouldhome £, richer. But thataposs what happened after her postcode came up trumps on Peopleaposs Postcode Lottery. Officials swooped on her street in Church Gresley, Derbyshire, before the lockdown after their postcode DE QL was picked as a winner. Three addresses were due to receive cheques - but when Gillian, , didnapost open her door, a frantic search was launched to find her. Cleaner Gillian recalled: “I was walking Eli, my friend’s dog, when my neighbour’s daughter said there were three winners on the street but the Postcode Lottery team could only find two of them!  Low and behold, I was the other winner they were looking for! It’s absolutely mad – things like this just don’t happen to people like me. Thrilled Gillian rushed home to receive her cheque - and said the cash will have a huge impact on her family. She added: I became a grandmother this year to two grandsons, with the youngest coming along just a few weeks ago so I’ll be able to help out the family, including my brother who is due to have surgery on both his knees soon.  I’m very boring so I’m not even after a holiday but I might treat myself to some new clothes as I’ve lost a bit of weight recently. I’m not in any rush to go mad and spend it all but I still work so this means I can relax a bit now. It’s such a comfort knowing that I don’t have to worry anymore. Gillianaposs neighbours Lisa Butcher, , and retired -year-old John Cockwill were the other winners celebrating on the street.

story: NewsMum-of-two angel whisperer who celebs have on speed dial for psychic readingsClaire Stone, who says she can see and speak to angels, grew up in poverty and uncertainty in Merseyside. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGrowing up, Claire Stone’s family thought she was talking to the devil. But now she uses her psychic abilities to give advice to the rich and famous. When Claire Stone’s phone buzzes with a message from model Tanya Bardsley or TV presenter Lizzie Cundy, she’s not surprised. Her contacts list is packed with stars from The Real Housewives Of Cheshire and The Only Way Is Essex. They rely on Claire to provide them with psychic readings and answers to their le ­questions. And when she’s not helping celebrities with their burning issues, Claire is teaching others how to ­connect with spirit guides through her workshops and courses. It’s a far cry from the poverty and uncertainty the -year-old faced when she grew up in Merseyside. From the age of two she lived with her mother and grandparents, after her dad left. Her grandparents died in her early teens, and when her mum became unwell Claire ended up becoming a young carer for her two-year-old twin sisters. “When I was  I was left to raise my sisters,” says Claire, who still lives in St Helens, Merseyside, with her husband John and daughters who are  and eight. “I was out of school looking after them. But I also had agoraphobia, which meant I struggled to go outside. “Sometimes social services would bring us beans and sacks of spuds, but I really think we slipped through the net.” Despite her mental health problems and unstable home le, Claire did have one thing she could rely on – her gt of talking to angels. “I’ve always been able to see angels but it wasn’t until I was about six that I realised my cousins didn’t have the same experiences as me,” reveals Claire. But her family were strict Christians who attended church every week.  “The vicar would say it was the devil’s work,” says Claire. As she grew older she struggled mentally. “I thought I was cursed because I had such a hideous le.” It was then, Claire says, she started to connect with an angel called Archangel Ariel. Ariel would come to Claire at night and she would hear her voice as a thought. “She started telling me how to cure my anxiety,” says Claire. She also had a deck of tarot cards and at  started doing readings for her friends. Now Claire has built her career around giving readings and teaching others to connect with their angel and spirit guides. “People often come because they are in two minds about relationships or careers. They have questions, like they are thinking of moving to a new country.”Claire has plenty of success stories to recount, most notably when Big Brother star Lisa Appleton was down on her luck.
