title: borders-professor-moots-return-national-service
story: A BORDERS professor has asked the UK Government to consider bringing back National Service.In an article published this week by The Times, military historian Sir Hew Strachan, Lord-Lieutenant of Tweeddale, was quoted from his report issued to the Ministry of Defence.In his report, Sir Hew said that bringing back National Service, which was phased out in , could help people better discuss the role of the military in the UK.The report also suggests that the military is expressed more like "a mythologised memory of the Second World War than an appreciation of armed conflict as it is experienced and conducted today.Tweeddale MP David Mundell told this newspaperhe is unsure about the idea of reinstating National Service, a programme which meant men aged - had to serve in one of the armed forces for  months.Mr Mundell said: ldquoWe already have a form of National Service emerging with the many thousands of public-spirited people coming forward to volunteer to help with the response to coronavirus.ldquoThe contribution in Tweeddale has been exceptional and that has been the case in many parts of Scotland and across the UK.ldquoMany young people have been doing their bit. We already have an lsquoarmyrsquo of volunteers and they are doing a fantastic job.ldquoIrsquom not sure we need to bring back National Service in the current circumstances. It could end up a bit of a distraction ldquoWe have very professional armed forces, who are currently doing a great deal to help, not all in the public domain."They are achieving a huge amount, particularly on the logistics front and supporting the expanded testing programme.Sir Hews report was commissioned by the Ministry of Defences development, concepts and doctrine centre , a ministry think-tank, in .

title: family-find-121-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A COUPLE have expressed their amazement at finding a -year-old copy of a local newspaper while renovating a historic Peebles building.Shona Haslam and her husband Marc purchased the old Peebles Courthouse in .But they were staggered when they discovered a perfectly preserved  edition of the Peebles News.Scottish Borders Council leader Mrs Haslam said: ldquoIt is a fantastic piece of local history and will definitely be finding a special place when the building is finally renovated.Justice was delivered from the former sherf court on the High Street for  years before its closure in .The Haslams bought the property three years ago and it will eventually become their family home, as well as holiday accommodation.The family were astonished when they found the old newspaper, costing one half-penny, dated February , .Mrs Haslam told us: ldquoI know DIY is a favourite lockdown activity for many, and in the Courthouse we have our fair share."While we were cleaning out, in one of the many boxes that we found when we moved in, I discovered this absolute gem of a Peebles Newsfrom ."She added: ldquoWhat always amazes me is how many of the names are still recognisable as well-kent within the town. You only need to look at the names of the committee of the March Riders meeting to see so many familiar surnames."The newspapers content included:A notice from the Town Clerk WM Buchan, requesting householders not to put paper in their ash buckets daily.Details of the Peebles Choral Society Annual ConcertAn auction sale of plants and shrubs in James Smithrsquos Auction Rooms at  and  Northgate, PeeblesAdverts for umbrella repairs by Turnbullrsquos John Dougallrsquos watchmaker, jeweller, cycle agent and optician John Greenrsquos winter clothing WM Weatherston  Son, Saddlers and Harness Makers Walter Mitchellrsquos Bootmaker, NorthgateHouses for sale ndash Cottages at Walkershaugh, Damdale, and Wemyss PlaceSports reports from Leithen Rovers, Peebles Rangers, Peebles Rovers, Walkerburn ThistleAn article detailing a public meeting of the Peebles March Riding which was presided over by Provost Ballantyne in the Town HallAn annual meeting of the Peebles Brass Band in the Masonic Hall where Chairman Mr J A Kerr presided over a most ldquomeagre attendance of the public, which he took as a sign that the public had no fault to find with their management

title: teacher-urges-athletes-run-virtual-three-bridges-races
story: DESPITE the annual Three Bridges Races in Peebles being cancelled this year, families are being asked to go the distance for the NHS.Due to coronavirus-related restrictions, the whistle was blown on the mass event which had been due to take place on Sunday.However, Peebles PE teacher Richard Edge has found a way over that hurdle and says people can still take part.He explained: ldquoDue to the current situation and the subsequent cancellation of numerous sporting events, I have no doubt that many of our young athletes will be missing a little bit of competition."I would like to invite anyone to run the equivalent distance of the infamous lsquoThree Bridges Racersquo which is . miles .k.Entry is free but competitors are being invited to make a donation through a fundraising page for the NHS.The Priorsford Primary teacher says the route does not have to cover the bridges.ldquoIn fact I would only suggest running this routevery early in the morning or later in the evening," he said."Itrsquos very important that you adhere to the current social distancing guidelines.ldquoItrsquos quite good fun working out a route, so work together with older family members and create one that suits you."This year, however, there will not be any gold medals being doled out. ldquoThe winner will receive absolutely nothing ndash just the joy of being part of the first virtual Three Bridges," said Mr Edge.Families can also take part in a team event, the teacher explained.ldquoAs we are spending longer with kids, a family run may be fun, Mr Edge said. "A group of three or more people can do a run and finish together. Your family timed run should be titled lsquo bridges virtual family runrsquo."Just as would-be competitors are being asked not to drive to their start lines, they are also being urged to obey social distancing rules when out running.Mr Edge said: ldquoBe considerate to other people by keeping a minimum of m distance at all times when passing. Runs must be completed solo, unless you are running as a family."Entrants are asked to submit their finishing times online before May .Mr Edge said: ldquoSome people will have access to a watch that will be able to time the run and will be linked to something like Strava map my run. If you do not have a watch, use a smart phone with one of the running apps open and record it that way."Once you have recorded your run, you are invited to title it lsquo bridges virtual runrsquo, take a screen shot and email it to: Gwedgerichard@glow.sch.uk, including your name and year of birth.Mr Edge added: ldquoA selfie at the finish of your run would be pretty cool. I will then try and use the information to create final results.If you would like to make a donation to the NHS, visit this website.

title: virus-test-centre-opens-galashiels-key-workers
story: KEY workers in the Borders who are self-isolating can now be tested for coronavirus in Galashiels.A centre at Netherdale car park is open from todayuntil May .The facility, run by the military, will allow key workers who are displaying symptoms to be tested for the virus, with family members also eligiblethey live under the same roof.Scottish Borders Councilsays the site poses no threat to the public, adding that all equipment will be removed at the end of each day.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: "I am delighted that we have managed to work with partners to quickly put in place plans to provide drive-through testing for key workers in the Scottish Borders."Irsquod urge any key worker who is self isolating, either because they themselves have symptoms of COVID- or because a member of their household is, to book tests."Testing is open to four priority groups, with those in Priority Group One already having access to NHS testing facilities.Priority Group Two includes "essential workers in critical national infrastructure fundamental for safety and security, and le-line services" Priority Group Three includes "staff directly involved in delivering other essential services" and Priority Group Four is for "staff involved in volunteering, or in nationally or locally signicant industry important to economic sustainability and growth".Key workers should visit this websiteto book their slot at the centre, which has been set up to support the UK Governments testing programme.

title: holiday-refunds---rights-get-money-back
story: Banks nationwide have blocked "billions of pounds" worth of refunds for holidays cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak.It is estimated that the public is collectively owed about pound billion from travel firms.Forced instead to turn to their banks for help, many customers have now been told they are not eligible for a refund.Heres what you need to know.Why arenrsquot travel firms giving refunds Consumer watchdog Which  recently revealed that  of the UKrsquos largest airlines and travel firms are illegally withholding refunds which should be paid to customers within  days.Instead, most customers have been offered vouchers or credit notes, with many complaining that they have been unable to claim a refund online, or get through to customer services on the phone to ask for their money back.Should I ask my bank for a refund Customers who have been refused a refund by travel firms and paid for their trip using a credit card can claim the money back from their provider under Section  of the Consumer Rights Act.Credit card providers are jointly liable with the retailer or trader for any breach of contract for misrepresentation, providing the value is more than pound and less than pound,.However, Which  has warned that some credit card customers have been told by their provider that theyre not eligible for a refund through the scheme.Others have been informed that their claim wonrsquot be processed until they have tried to claim the cash from the travel firm first, even though this is not a legal requirement.Customers are also able to claim through a process known as chargeback, which allows a transaction to be reversedyou are unable to resolve a dispute, including services not delivered.This covers all card payments and is a process agreed between financial institutions and the relevant card scheme, such as Mastercard and Visa.What are Mastercard and Visarsquos chargeback rights Mastercard said there is a chargeback right where firms have cancelled goods or services, even where this is due to government restrictions, insolvency or other exceptional circumstances.It is also validthe cardholder doesnrsquot wish to accept the firmrsquos offer to rebook or claim a voucher, but the issue should first be attempted to be resolved with the firm.Visarsquos guidance also states that firms should process a refund promptlycustomers decline a credit note or voucher, and cardholders do have a right to complain when goods or services are not provided.However, Visa does make an exception where firms have failed to provide a service due to a government-imposed travel ban, stating that this ldquosupersedes Visa rules on dispute rights.For this reason, Mastercard customers are likely to be more successful when making chargeback claims for coronavirus-related cancellations.If flights are cancelled due to closed borders, customers will still have a dispute right under both Mastercard and Visa, as EU-wide rules around refunds override the government travel ban, according to Which .Which banks will refund under Section  and chargeback Banks have said that they will assess each case inidually when it comes to refunds from firms only offering credit notes or rebooking a cancelled trip.This is what the major banks told Which  about issuing refunds:Where a provider has not met their legal obligations to the customer, Barclays will consider both chargeback and Section  claims, provided the relevant criteria are met.HSBC, including First Directand MS Bank, will allow a chargeback or Section  claim to be made for goods or services not received, but customers are encouraged to contact their airline first.Lloyds Group, including Halaxand Bank of Scotlandsay thata refund is not offered by the travel firm and a customer has proof of this, the bank can pursue a disputed transaction claim under scheme rules.Bankrsquos position is that every chargeback and dispute is dferent, and each claim will need to be assessed on a case-by-case basis with the customer to work out the best solution.Nationwidealso says each case will be looked at on a case-by-case basis because it depends on the type of good services being purchased and what the terms of the agreement are with the merchant.Similarly, RBS, including Natwestand Ulster Bank, said cases would be considered on an inidual basis.If a claim made with the merchant in the first instance is not satisfactory, customers can contact Santanderto raise a claim.,params: .pushWhere the merchant has offered the chance to rebook for free and or provide vouchers and the customer is not satisfied with this then Starling Banksays it would initiate a chargeback.If a merchant is not offering a refund, or are asking customers to contact their card issuers to process a refund, Tesco Bankcustomers can raise a dispute.The Co-operative Banksays thatcustomers tried to resolve the issue with the merchant first but there was no refund or resolution, the bank would look at each case inidually to verya dispute chargeback right existed. If a chargeback right existed but the cardholder accepted a credit voucher, this would not affect the cardholderrsquos original dispute rights. The bank would also not reject a Section  claim outright in these circumstances.If customers are offered a voucher or a chance to rebook, TSBwould typically accept the claims and each case will be considered inidually.If the customer is unhappy with the solution offered by the merchant, Virgin Moneywould consider the terms and conditions. If the alternative arrangements are not covered, a chargeback would normally be successful. Section  claims will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

title: 5g-mast-proposed-galashiels-council-land
story: PLANS for a G mast in Galashiels have been lodged with Scottish Borders Council .The applicationwould see the .-metresteel pole placed on the verge of the townrsquos King Street, on land owned by the council.Residents are now able to submit their views on the proposal, put forward by Harlequin Group on behalf of EE Ltd.Galashielscouncillor Euan Jardine said: "I believe it is important for our local economy that we are on level terms with other towns throughout the country in regards to G provision."It will also have some positive aspects for recreational usage and help to usher in advancements in technology that will change a lot of how we go about our daily lives."Mr Jardine added that he had not been approached by any residents about the application.Meanwhile, his ward colleagueHarry Scott told the Border he was not aware of the plans.Mr Scott said: "I would need to study the application and the circumstances around it before coming to any conclusions."The application, ref   C, can be viewed on the council website.

title: borders-homes-can-book-virtual-visit-auctioneer-bonhams
story: BORDERS residents have the chance to invite a world-famous auctioneer to look round their homes this week.Bonhams is delivering a free valuation service through video conferencing apps.And this week, households in the Borders are under the spotlight, with residents being asked to dig out paintings, jewellery, furniture and collectables.Bonhams Scotland managing director Charles Graham-Campbell said: "Wersquore trying to adapt and do these valuations in a way thatrsquos safe for everybody.Appointments are available from Tuesday until Thursday , am to pm.Items that can be assessed include paintings, silver, jewellery, ceramics, glass, clocks, works of art, furniture, Asian items, and collectables such as whisky.Mr Graham-Campbell, , said: ldquoWersquove always provided valuations where people have sent in photographs but we havenrsquot actually done a Zoom, Teams or WhatsApp virtual meeting ndash a video going round a house looking at objects.ldquoSo this is something new, itrsquos the antique world adapting to the situation we currently find ourselves in. Like other places, we are shut down at the moment."We canrsquot do a lot of work, but wersquore happy to try and help people where we can.Mr Graham-Campbell said it is more useful to see the house via video than to have photographs sent to the company.He said: ldquoWersquore quite used to handling photographs and working from photographs as a profession."It is always best to handle things, and there is always a caveat that the valuation is subject to further research.ldquoBut when we ask people to send in a photograph, they send in a photo of what they think is valuable, and what they think is a family heirloom."But so often when we go to a house, wersquore asked to go and look at a piece of furniture, for example, but actually itrsquos a small Chinese vase, sitting inside a cabinet, thatrsquos the valuable little item and theyrsquoll make more money than all the furniture put together. And they wonrsquot have necessarily known that.Even during the COVID- crisis, valuations continue to be required, Mr Graham-Campbell said.ldquoPeople take over something or inherit it and suddenly need an accurate insurance valuation and we can again have a look round and provide a stopgap valuation, until the times when we can do things in the correct manner, said Mr Graham-Campbell.ldquoThings that are being valued for a business need to be done to comply with their insurance every five years or something."Items need to be valued either for insurance or for probate, or executry purposes."Much of Bonhamsrsquo business is auctioneering, which has also had to be put on hold.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWith the situation as it is now, there are some people wanting to raise a sum of money and theyrsquove maybe invested in antiques in the past and theyrsquore using that as part of their pension fund.,params: .push"Theyrsquove maybe spent more on buying some paintings than putting into a pension fund and then theyrsquore wanting to realise those assets just to live or give something to their children who are having a hard time and not working at the moment.Scottish auctions normally take place at the Bonhams venue in Queen Street, Edinburgh, and these will also now be taking place online.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWersquore starting to do virtual auctions ndash wersquove done online auctions in the past, so wersquore quite used to doing them, but wersquore starting to work out how we can do more of them and then wersquore going to do a live auction behind closed doors."Wersquore hopefully going to be able to do that with maybe a live auctioneer and telephone bidders working from home and a clerk at a safe distance away."But the actual venue will be shut to the general public, and the public will be at home bidding away on their computers.ldquoThere are ways that we can work in a safe manner in the near future.To book a virtual valuation appointment, or for more information, email valuations.scotland@bonhams or call Charles Graham-Campbell on

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. Big sellers include roast beef, lasagne and sweet and sour dishes.ldquoThe amount of mince Irsquove sold is just incredible. And wersquove got a full-time pie man and hersquos just having to work his socks off, Mr Baird said, adding: ldquoWersquore the lucky ones, being busy ndash I feel for some people.In a joint statement, the four shop owners said they are ldquoincredibly thankful for the help provided by volunteers.Commending their efforts, the statement added: ldquoThey are actively committed to continuing to provide this essential doorstep service to all those who require it.

title: jack-lowden-invites-entries-earlston-high-talent-show
story: ACTOR Jack Lowden has urged pupils at Earlston High School to take part in a talent competition.The former Earlston student starred in a video on Facebook this week appealing for entries to Earlstonrsquos Got Virtual Talent.Lowden invited pupils to submit video clips of themselves doing "something really cool and extraordinary".The -second clips should be sent through Show My Homework, he said, between May  and June .Giving examples of the talent being sought, Lowden said performances may showcase cooking, acting, singing, dancing, football skills or dog routines.When entries are received, judges will whittle them down to a shortlist and then the public will vote for the winner."There will be an almighty bonanza of a prize for the person that wins," said Lowden, calling on pupils to "have some fun".Lowden, who received an Olivier Award in , has appeared in films including Dunkirkand Mary, Queen of Scots.

title: mays-super-flower-moon-see-uk
story: A so-called lsquoFlower Moonrsquo will be spotted over the skies of the UK this week.Not only that, but Mays full moon will also be a supermoon, making it a Super Flower Moon.But just what does all that mean What is a Flower Moon The May full moon is traditionally known as the Flower Moon simply because it appears at the time of blossoming flowers.What is a supermoon The moon - our planets only natural satellite - actually follows an elliptical orbit around the Earth.This means that at certain points on its egg-shaped path, it can be further away, or closer to us - a dferential of about , miles.The closest point is called the perigee, and the furthest is the apogee. When a full moon falls on the perigee, it appears far bigger and brighter in the sky and becomes known as a supermoon.The phenomenon is not actually that rare, and this months is last in a trilogy that began with Marchs full moon..During a supermoon,the diameter of the moon canappear to be about  per cent greater than an average full moon.What timewill the moon be biggest The full moon will be in the night sky on the evening of Thursday, May , though it will technically be at its fullest at :am on Thursday morning.Seeing as it wont even be in the sky then - let alone visible in daylight - the fullest youll get to see the moon will come at around .pm on Thurday, when the moon rises.It will be in the sky all night, and wont set again until about .am the following morning, offering plenty of time for you to catch a glimpse.For the best effect ndash and the closest yoursquoll get to witnessing the spectacular images seen across social media following such an event ndash yoursquoll want to look east shortly after moonrise.ldquoWhen the moon is near the horizon, it can look unnaturally large when viewed through trees, buildings, or other foreground objects," say NASA."The effect is an optical illusion, but that fact doesnrsquot take away from the experience."What  should I look out for This months full moon ties in nicely with the peak of the Eta Aquariids meteor shower.The meteor shower has been going on above our heads for a couple of weeks, and runs roughly from April  - May .However, it is this week when budding astronomers are likely to get the best show, as the shower peaks on the night of May  into May .The Eta Aquariids should be visible with the naked eye, although the glare from a full supermoon will make them harder to spot.Those living in built up areas would usually be advised to travel to less populated spaces and to avoid light pollutionthey really want to see the shower, but with ongoing lockdown restrictions and the coronavirus pandemic, that is not advised.Wrapping up in warm clothes is recommended, and you should allow up to  minutes for your eyes to fully adjust to the night sky.The Eta Aquariids are not one of the years most spectacular meteor showers, and usually peak at around  meteors per hours - thats just under one a minute.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: 65th-anniversary-couple-met-galashiels-academy
story: A COUPLE will celebrate their th anniversary today by speaking to family over Zoom.Charlie and Evelyn Renton, of St Boswells, were married on May , , at Melrose Parish Church.With coronavirus restrictions in place, a traditional family reunion is not possible ndash but the pair have been looking forward to a virtual get-together.Reflecting on their long marriage, Mrs Renton, , said: ldquoWersquove been very happy and healthy and very lucky.The couple, who first met at Galashiels Academy, moved from Mr Rentonrsquos native Galashiels to the Republic of Ireland in .Mrs Renton, originally from Melrose, had qualied as a nurse in Edinburgh, while Mr Renton, , enjoyed a career as a textile designer.The couple have three children , three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.They ed to the Borders in , moving into their current home in St Boswells.

title: countries-split-easing-coronavirus-lockdowns
story: Regional and political isions have emerged in many nations over how fast to lt coronavirus lockdowns as worries about economic devastation collide with fears of a second wave of deaths.In France, more than  mayors in the Paris region have urged President Emmanuel Macron to delay the reopening of schools scheduled for Monday.Many mayors around the country have already refused to reopen schools and many parents will keep their children at home even where they are ing again.The mayors called the timing ldquountenable and unrealistic, saying they were put on a ldquoforced march to get schools ready without enough staff or equipment, and complained that the government guidelines were too vague and slow in coming.vw,vw,px, px"But governments are also under pressure to reopen faster and kick-start economies that have been plunged into hibernation.Italian regional governors are pressing to open shops and restaurants, just days after the country began easing its two-month lockdown, allowing . million people toto work in offices and factories.Governors are seeking to be allowed to present their own plans for reopening, tailored to the rate of infection and economic needs of their regions.In Germany, whose  state governments are responsible for imposing and loosening lockdowns, some governors have been more impatient than others to open up businesses such as restaurants and hotels.At a meeting on Wednesday with Chancellor Angela Merkel, it was agreed that state leaders would have wide leeway to decide when to open more sectors of the economy. They also will have to reimpose restrictions locallycoronavirus infections rebound.In Russia, where the number of new infections is growing fast, President Vladimir Putin delegated the enforcement of lockdowns and other restrictions to regional governments, leading to wide iations across the country.vw,vw,px, px"Russian President Vladimir Putin has given regional governments powers to make decisions on lockdowns Mikhail Vinogradov, head of the St Petersburg Politics think tank, told the Vedomosti newspaper that the Moscow government was sending mixed messages that governors find hard to decipher mdash wanting a victory over the virus while also encouraging easing of the lockdown.Fractures are also evident in the US, where about half of the  states are easing their shutdowns, to the alarm of public health officials.Many states have not put in place the robust testing and contact tracing that experts believe is necessary to detect and contain new outbreaks.And many governors have pressed ahead with reopening before their states have met one of the key benchmarks in the administrationrsquos guidelines for reopening mdash a -day downward trajectory in new infections.ldquoIf we relax these measures without having the proper public health safeguards in place, we can expect many more cases and, unfortunately, more deaths, said Josh Michaud, associate director of global health policy with the Kaiser Family Foundation in Washington.Researchers recently doubled their projection of deaths in the US to about , through early August. So far the US has recorded over , deaths and . million confirmed infections.Worldwide, the virus has infected more than . million people and killed over a quarter of a million, according to a Johns Hopkins University tally, which experts agree understates the dimensions of the pandemic because of limited testing, dferences in counting the dead and concealment by some governments.Europe and North America are looking nervously to Asian nations that are well on the way to reopening.China, where the virus emerged late last year, reported just two new cases on Thursday, both from overseas, and said the whole country now is at low risk of further infections after confirming no new deaths from Covid- in more than three weeks.vw,vw,px, px"China is now said to be a low risk China also fired back against claims by US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo that there is ldquoenormous evidence that the coronavirus originated in a Chinese laboratory.Foreign Ministry spokesman Hua Chunying accused Mr Pompeo of ldquomaking up lies and covering up a lie by fabricating more lies.Strict social distancing also appears to have vanquished the outbreak in New Zealand, where Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern outlined plans for further relaxing lockdown rules, with a decision coming perhaps next week.New Zealand would keep its borders shut, restrict gatherings to  people or fewer and hold professional sports events without spectators. Masks and other precautions would be required as restaurants and schools reopen, she said. But Ms Ardern called for vigilance.ldquoWe think of ourselves as halfway down Everest, Ms Ardern said. ldquoI think itrsquos clear that no one wants to hike back up that peak..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Countries split over easing of coronavirus lockdowns

title: baby-born-weighing-just-one-pound-survives-goes-home
story: A ldquomiracle baby girl who weighed just lb ozwhen she was born more than four months prematurely has safely gone home from hospital.Mother Tayla Menear, , gave birth to Lilly at Norfolk and Norwich University Hospital on December  last year,  weeks into her pregnancy.Baby Lilly was allowed to leave the ward on Tuesday after four months of round-the-clock care, having grown to lb oz She is now being cared for at home near Fakenham in Norfolk by mother Ms Menear, a specialist support assistant, and -year-old father Shane Rumbles, who works for a buildersrsquo merchants." srcset"https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dfc-ee--bc-dfcedc.jpg w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dfc-ee--bc-dfcedc.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dfc-ee--bc-dfcedc.jpg w w" sizes" vw, px"Baby Lilly was born at  weeks weighing just over one pound A large team of doctors and nurses helped Lilly overcome three serious infections and a bleed on her brain, for which she had to undergo major surgery.Ms Menear said: ldquoWe owe all the staff at the Norfolk and Norwich Hospital Neonatal Intensive Care Unit everything ndash for saving our little  week miracle.Consultant neonatologist Dr Priya Muthukumar, who helped save Lilly, said it is too early to predict exactly what Lillyrsquos long-term outcome will be, but added: ldquoIn terms of her longer prognosis, itrsquos looking pretty good.The hospitalrsquos chief executive Sam Higginson said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted that Lilly has made such good progress and that she has been able to go home.ldquoThese have been challenging times for Tayla and Shane and I wish them all the joy in the world..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Baby born weighing just over one pound survives and goes home

title: celebs-give-energy-saving-tips-lockdown-life
story: From frantic spring cleaning to a digital detox, famous faces across the UK are attempting to save energy in lockdown - and not by sitting on the sofa.As the nation hits  days behind closed doors, green-living celebrities admit they are more mindful than ever about their energy use.Nature presenter Chris Packham has been vacuuming the back of his radiators and cleaning the coils at the back his fridge to make them more efficient.TV presenter Helen Skelton has ditched her beloved hairdryer for an lsquoau naturelrsquo look.And two-time Olympic swimming champion Rebecca Adlington is fuelling her baking obsession in the microwave - not the oven.ldquoAs a household wersquore trying to do energy-free time, said Adlington.ldquoDuring the week, wersquove introduced TV-free time between am and pm and wersquore trying to do this at the weekend too, filling our time with other activities.ldquoWhether thatrsquos doing a jigsaw, which Irsquove realised Irsquom terrible at, or doing arts and crafts with my daughter, reading books and playing board games, exercising, dancing using a dferent energy.ldquoSomething wersquove found really useful is our smart meter. We all know our energy will be increasing during this time, butyou have one already, it can help you to keep a track on things.#AD@smartenergyGB#asked me how were currently conserving energy at home.#What do you do in your home to be more energy efficient  Comment below with your tips. Your ideas might help others make some savings too! #energysavingtipspic hdutKCsoDmdash Becky AdlingtonMay , percent of people who have a smart meter are using the device to track their spending and try to reduce their energy usage and Smart Energy GB is sharing these tips to help people with their energy consumption during this timeCountryfile star Skelton is keeping her , Instagram followers updated on her lockdown regime with children Ernie, four, and Louis, three.And while the next two days are promising to be glorious - she has some advice for when next weekrsquos predicted cold snap hits.ldquoItrsquos too easy to turn on the heating to warm up, instead, warm up by getting the jumpers out of the wardrobe, she said.ldquoWe also keep moving - assault courses around the house and gymnastics classes in the lounge so the kids donrsquot turn the heating on!CELEBS TOP TEN TIPS TO SAVE ENERGY. Try making some cakes in the microwave, rather than the oven. Make lsquoenergy-freersquo time a part of your day e.g. leaving the TV off and doing a jigsaw or reading a book. Remember to turn lights off in rooms that arenrsquot being used. If you have a smart meter, use it to keep track of your energy and identy where you might be able to cut down your consumption during lockdown.. Rather than turning the heating on, put a jumper on or even keep warm by dancing and exercising. Let your hair dry naturally rather than blow drying. Set up your workspace near a window to make the most of natural light ndash itrsquoll mean you donrsquot need a light on and is a good mood enhancer. Clean the back of your fridge to make it more energy efficient ndash when the coils get fluffy the fridge has to work harder. Clean down the back of radiators - dust on the columns prevents the heat from flowing freely. Batch cook your meals rather than frequent small cooking sessions

title: couples-diamond-anniversary-party-hold-thanks-virus
story: Robert and Kay Mackie, of North Crescent, celebrated  years of marriage on April .They had originally planned a meal with  close friends and family at the Prestoungrange Gothenburg on April , but the dinner had to be postponed.Robert was born in Edinburgh on November , , and has lived in Prestonpans all his le, attending local primary and high schools.He worked in a garage and then as a miner, working in dferent pits until his retirement in .He is a keen golfer and a member of the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club.Kay was born in Canada on November , , but moved with her family to Carmichael, Lanark, when she was three or four years old.The pair met dancing at the Cavendish club in Edinburgh in May , and were engaged at Christmas the same year.They married a year later at Glencorse Church, near Penicuik.Kay worked in an office until she and Robert started their own family Sheila was born in  and Diana in .The family lived in Cockenzie for seven years before moving to Prestonpans. Robert and Kay have now lived in the same house for  years.Sheila explained why her parents had decided to marry on April .She said: ldquoMy mumrsquos only brother, Michael Robertson, was emigrating back to Canada and she wanted him at the wedding.ldquoThat was the only date they could get before he emigrated he moved back the week after and still lives there now. It was nothing to do with April Foolrsquos Day!The pair have three grandchildren, one great grandson and two step-great granddaughters. Sheilarsquos eldest son, Calum, was born in  and she said the new grandparents were soon taking on babysitting duties.Sheila said: ldquoTheyrsquore really family orientated and helped a lot with bringing the kids up. They would go to their house after school.With celebration plans now on hold, the family instead spent part of the morning waving to the happy couple from afar.Sheila said: ldquoWe went round in the morning and waved in the window. It was nice to see them theyrsquore celebrating so many years married.When asked their secret to a long and happy marriage, Sheila added: ldquoThey said to listen to each other and to not go to bed on an argument.

title: heavy-sound-bit-put-food-table
story: Heavy Sound, based in Tranent, has joined forces with other groups, including the townrsquos Fundamental Foods, to help get food to those in need.The social enterprise is also working alongside the Edinburgh International Conference Centre .With conferences and events at the city venue cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak, Heavy Sound is partnering them to distribute food from the EICCrsquos kitchens to vulnerable communities in and around Edinburgh.Jordan Butler, Heavy Sound CEO, said: ldquoAlthough we canrsquot deliver our usual programmes at schools, we have resources and staff who are willing to support in whatever way they can.ldquoWe were already dealing with food poverty and isolation in our communities, something that has only been exacerbated by the pandemic.ldquoLow income, mental health, complex trauma and unemployment are factors at play, and the only silver lining has been around how people and businesses like the EICC are pulling together and collaborating in new ways to make a dference.Heavy Sound usually uses music, arts and sport to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Last year, the social enterprise revealed plans to title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen title: burger-king-greggs-kfc-nandos-mcdonalds-preparing-reopen-uk-stores
story: As of yesterday - heres what we know so far.GreggsGreggshaveconfirmed it islooking to reopen with a number of stores expected to reopen their doorsasearly as next week.The bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.Although the full details of how the trial will operate have not been released, it is believed a number ofNewcastlestores will be among the first to welcome customers back.But due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday, April : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonaldsNo confirmed date has been revealed as to when McDonalds will , but work is going on behind the scenes to prepare for a small-but-steadyacross the country.Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos CEO UK and Ireland said on Tuesday, April :"In March, we took the decision to temporarily close our restaurants in the UK and Ireland for the safety of our people and customers. Recently, we began working through a potential and limited reopening."We have been listening to our employees and customers as well as engaging with government and trade bodies to help ensure we do this responsibly, when the time is right."Restarting our business is not an easy task even when reopening in a limited capacity. We have set ourselves some key criteria for reopening, all of which take time ndash first and foremost ensuring the wellbeing of our people and creating the right environment for them toto work secondly ensuring we have enough supply of fresh produce and finally working in-step with government guidelines to ensure the safety of our customers."This week we are carrying out some operational tests to explore what our reopening might look like the restaurant where these tests take place will remain closed to the public."These tests will include exploring social distancing measures for our crew, PPE options and opening in a limited capacity."For now we remain closed, and will only reopen when we are absolutely confident we can have the right measures in place to ensure everyonersquos wellbeing.Burger KingBurger King has revealed it will open  more restaurants across the country.The move comes after the recentre-opening of six branches - all offering alimited menu to customers chain said it will reopen the kitchens of four restaurants in London and two in Manchester to offer a delivery service through Deliveroo.It comes after Nandorsquos restarted cooking at these sites last week to serve food for NHS workers and charities.The restaurant chain said it will offer deliveries from its Camberwell, Canary Jubilee, Clink Street and Gloucester Road sites in London.It will also serve customers in Manchester from its Fallowfield and Printworks locations.Nandorsquos said it will offer a reduced delivery menu from these sites, but will not be offering eat-in or collection services.In a statement, Nandorsquos said: ldquoThe menu will be reduced to help the team maintain social distance in the kitchen and food prep areas, but never fear as the majority of Nandorsquos favourites such as peri-peri chicken wings, halloumi and peri chips will now be available to enjoy at home.ldquoEach Nandorsquos restaurant has been working under Public Health England guidelines for a successful trial re-opening serving meals to local good causes, they are now upping production to serve the public.The company stressed that this is the ldquofirst phase of its reopening plans but more restaurants could follow suit and open for deliveriesit is successful.Nandorsquos said that each restaurant will also continue to cook meals every sht for local charities and NHS workers.KFCKFC is set to reopen moreof its branches across the country after bringing in a new set of rules to keep staff and customers safe.The fast-foodretailer began closing its stores on March  following the governments decision to place the UK on lockdown.At that time, KFC said that it wanted to "protect the wellbeing and safety" of staff and customers, and confirmed that the temporary closures would be "until further notice."It was then revealed earlier this month that eleven stores would reopen as part of an initial phase, including two sites in Manchester.The chain is however offering a "limited menu" to customers and service is delivery-only, available through Deliveroo, Just Eat and Uber Eats for those who live near one of the restaurants.In a statement about reopening stores, KFC workers across the country are doing a phenomenal job. title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: athelstaneford-primary-school-takes-talent-show-online

title: tesco-manager-puts-thank-notices-trolleys

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. He also argued that the public need to know what the government has planned in terms of a lockdown exit strategy.Speaking to , he said: ldquoPeople are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. The public would allegedly be allowed back into outdoor spaces first, with pubs being the last to open, as the lockdown was lted.Cabinet Office minister, Michael Gove, confirmed that areas of hospitality will be among the last to see restrictions lted.When asked whether pubs would open ldquobefore winter, Mr Gove told Sky News: ldquoThe other inference that I draw from your question, which is that areas of hospitality will be among the last to exit the lockdown - yes, that is true.What about cinemas and theatres Professor Winter has also been advising ministers on how to go about lting lockdown, and said cinemas and theatres could also reopen, but must have half empty auditoriums.Every other seat would have to be unoccupied, but he said venues could make up for the loss of money by raising ticket prices.

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. Hersquos looking forward to trying the cake.Jim was born in Gullane on April ,  but has spent most of his le in North Berwick, attending the local schools.He spent all of his career as a quantity surveyor and is a member of the local bowling club.He met Valerie, who is from Prestonpans, at the Pavilion dances in North Berwick, where the Scottish Seabird Centre now stands.The pair married  years ago.Morag said: ldquoWe were going to come over with the whole family and help him celebrate. I ended up phoning him on the day.ldquoThe plan is to hopefully get something arranged when this is all over.ldquoHe also got fish and chips delivered for his dinner.Morag added: ldquoIrsquod just like to say to the community a big thank you.ldquoItrsquos a good thing they have done, especially the people who made the cake.Thank you for reading this story. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: family-wake-find-trapped-vandal-screws-gate-shut
story: Aislinn and Charles Balderston, of Clford Road, North Berwick, and their sons Frankie, , Arthur and Teddy, both , were trapped in their front garden when they tried to leave the property to take the twins to the GP surgery.ldquoWe were watching TV one night, said Mrs Balderston, ldquoAnd we heard this really funny noise, like a drill or something. title: volunteers-dishing-hundreds-hot-meals
story: The centre is working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council on the initiative, with staff at the centre cooking the meals.More than  volunteers at the local resilience group are helping with packing and deliveries.As many as  families are receiving hot meals or food donations, with deliveries made every day. title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave

title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. story: Pinkie Farm Convenience Store, one of Nisarsquos independent outlets, has donated essentials to the vulnerable and families in the area who are struggling with financial hardship.Support from the store ndash led by managing director Dan Brown ndash has included a pound donation to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, pound to Resilient Musselburgh and a further pound to Pennypit Community Development Trust.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes provide fresh produce boxes containing all the ingredients needed to prepare a full roast dinner to struggling families.The charityrsquos founder, Jane Russell, said the donation would provide  local families with their dinner boxes.She commented: ldquoI set up the project in December  to give out free fresh chicken dinner boxes to people financially struggling in East Lothian.ldquoThe idea was to create a box of fresh produce so they had everything to cook a Sunday roast chicken dinner, and so the families could all sit together and enjoy a healthy meal.ldquoWe have helped over  families so far. The reason I set it up was because I myself have been in that position and, with three kids, financially struggling is so hard, decidingyou can afford food or gas.ldquoI wanted to make our project easy for people to ask for help without any forms to fill in or feel embarrassed.ldquoThe feedback and the support from the local community to help us is just amazing. The donation we received from Nisa will provide  families with our fresh chicken dinner boxes, which is just amazing.The donations were made via Nisarsquos lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo charity which raises funds in-store from the sale of Co-op and Heritage own brand products and has seen the Pinkie Farm Convenience Store donate almost pound, to local causes.The donations are just one of many ways in which the store is reaching out to support the local community, having recently launched new pound lsquoessentials kitsrsquo aimed at helping the most vulnerable people in the community and those who are self-isolating.Food kits have also been given to staff at Musselburgh Primary Health Care Centre and fresh produce contributed to East Lothian Foodbank, amongst other initiatives to help those most in need.Thank you for reading this story.
